Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Digitization TCN: Mobilizing New England Vascular Plant Specimen Data to Track Environmental Changes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Herbarium specimens provide a source of historical information useful to the study of global environmental change. The goal of this project is to provide data to support studies of the nature and consequences of environmental change in the New England region over the last three centuries. This project will digitally capture specimen data and images from about 1.3 million vascular plant specimens from herbaria across New England, enhancing the data with georeferencing, habitat, and phonological information. The digitization process will integrate with existing community efforts and will develop novel high-throughput digitization technologies to increase efficiency and decrease costs. All resulting data and images will be freely available on-line.

The data from this project will be of immediate use to scientists who study climate and land-use change, and will provide a better understanding of how global changes will impact the distribution of native and introduced plant species. This project will benefit research in taxonomy, ecology, morphology, biogeography, and evolutionary history by making available data on an entire regional flora in an electronic format. The methodologies developed will provide a model for other regions around the nation. In addition the project will utilize citizen scientists, school groups, and students providing training, research, and educational opportunities. . This award is made as part of the National Resource for Digitization of Biological Collections through the Advancing Digitization of Biological Collections program and all data resulting from this award will be available through the national resource (iDigBio.org).

Performance_Institution.Name: Yale Peabody Museum of Natural History

POR.DRECONTENT:
The billions of specimens housed in natural history collections provide a source of under-utilized information that are useful for scientific research, conservation, commerce, and education. Herbarium specimens, which document plant occurrences over the last three plus centuries, provide a rich source of data for understanding environmental change at various scales. Capturing the temporal and spatial information associated with specimens into digital form, a process called digitization, and then sharing this data online promises to greatly increase the utilization of the specimens for research. The primary goal of the New England Vascular Plants Project (NEVP) was to create to an herbarium specimen data set catered to the study of the effects of climate change and land use history in New England. New England’s rich and comprehensive botanical collections, varied landscape, and history of disturbance make it an ideal region for such study.

As part of its contribution to the NEVP project, Yale digitized specimens from its collection and eight other smaller, regional collections, capturing over 160,000 specimen images and creating almost 140,000 specimen records with information about when and where the specimens were collected and their reproductive condition. The resulting images and data were shared on the internet through various data sharing websites utilized by scientists, conservationists, educators, and the general public. These websites include the iDigBio portal (portal.iDigBio.org) and the Consortium of Northeastern Herbaria portal (portal.neherbaria.org). These data will be of immediate use to scientists who study environmental change. In addition, the overall project will significantly benefit many other areas of scientific research by helping to make available specimen data from an entire region in an electronic format that is globally accessible. Such information is critical for a range of investigations in taxonomy, ecology, conservation, biogeography, and evolutionary history.

This project had significant training and education outcomes and other broader impacts. Five high school students and over forty undergraduate and graduate students were involved in the project. They were introduced to biodiversity informatics and museum collection curation and management and they learned about the relevance of natural history collections to science. Through the iDigBio portal and other venues, the results of our activities will be of use to a diverse group of stakeholders including the general public, educators and students, and national and regional agencies charged with managing natural resources, to name a few.
